item.title: Covid: Care home isolation rule axed for low-risk trips in England
item.description: The rules will be relaxed in England - allowing for day trips without 14 days' quarantine afterwards.

item.title: Covid-19: Scientist urges patience before 17 May lockdown relaxation
item.description: Government adviser Prof Sir Mark Walport says there is "good news" but the virus could "reignite".

item.title: US and Nato start to formally withdraw troops from Afghanistan
item.description: The move will bring to an end the US' longest war but prompted a new warning from the Taliban.

item.title: Noel Clarke: Report made to police after allegations against actor
item.description: The actor denies any sexual misconduct or criminal wrongdoing and no police investigation has begun.

item.title: Five arrested in right-wing terror raids across England and Wales
item.description: A 16-year-old boy is among five people held in a series of raids across England and Wales.

item.title: India coronavirus: Over-18s vaccination drive hit by shortages
item.description: States say they don't have enough doses for people aged 18-45, as new coronavirus cases pass 400,000.

item.title: Clubbers' joy at returning to the dance floor in Liverpool
item.description: DJs and dancers share their experiences of the "big energy" at the first club night since lockdown.

item.title: Children will suffer, Unicef warns as UK funding cut by 60%
item.description: The government says the "tough decision" to reduce its contributions by 60% was due to the pandemic.

item.title: Israel crush: Israel mourns as festival crush victims identified
item.description: Some 32 of those killed in a stampede at a Jewish festival are identified, with funerals to follow.

item.title: PCSO Julia James: Searches as murder probe enters fifth day
item.description: Mourners continue laying flowers in Aylesham, including tributes from the family of Julia James.

item.title: May Day Morris dancers wear blue makeup over racism concerns
item.description: The group in Hampshire says it is "by far and away the biggest change" in its 30-year history.

item.title: Mali: The world's 'most dangerous peacekeeping mission'
item.description: British troops have joined what is considered the world's most dangerous UN peacekeeping force in Mali.

item.title: Week in pictures: 24 - 30 April 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images taken around the world this week.

item.title: Do you know where plastic waste in the oceans is coming from?
item.description: The Ocean Cleanup suggests plastic pollution comes from more rivers in the world than previously thought.

item.title: Why is this the 'most instagrammable' bird?
item.description: How a study designated the rare, odd-looking frogmouth the most instagrammable of avian species.

item.title: Giant 300-tonne fatberg blocks Birmingham sewer
item.description: Severn Trent says the mass of oil, grease and "unflushable" items could take until June to clear.

item.title: HMS Unicorn goes under the microscope for preservation project
item.description: A major survey of HMS Unicorn is under way in Dundee as part of a major preservation project.

item.title: Planning my 'big Greek wedding' in a pandemic
item.description: Restrictions on wedding guest numbers are due to be lifted on 21 June, but couples are still anxious.

item.title: The Papers: 'Holidays from 17 May' and 'care home freedom'
item.description: Saturday's papers include details of plans to further ease lockdown restrictions in England.

item.title: Swimming with my stoma bag
item.description: Gill Castle is on a mission to break down fear and stigma around taking to the water with a colostomy pouch.

item.title: 'Disaster Girl' sells iconic meme for £340,000
item.description: Zoë Roth, 21, will use the money from the sale of a 2005 image of her to pay her student loan.

item.title: Cornholme erotic books note attacks 'cesspit' Hebden Bridge
item.description: A village goes viral when an angry note appears on its book-swap box railing against "filthy" titles.

item.title: Long-distance relationships are tough - but lockdown helped this couple
item.description: "In the first lockdown we couldn't see each other. This is round two, just an ocean apart."

item.title: Bobby Sands: The hunger strike that changed the course of N Ireland's conflict
item.description: A hunger strike in which 10 IRA prisoners died was a watershed in the Troubles, says Peter Taylor.

item.title: Domestic Abuse Bill: For these victims, a new law is long overdue
item.description: The landmark Domestic Abuse Bill became law this week. Two survivors describe what it means for them.

item.title: Britney Spears: Does the latest documentary tell us anything new?
item.description: Another new documentary examining the singer's conservatorship is released this weekend.

item.title: Singapore: What's it like in the best place to live during Covid?
item.description: As the pandemic continues to devastate, one Asian island has emerged as the best place to ride it out.

item.title: Election 2021: 'I was homeless now I'm voting for the first time'
item.description: Aaron Scullion was homeless at 21 but he now has a job and home and is voting for the first time.

item.title: Covid: Fears of 'impending doom' in Pakistan
item.description: A slow vaccine roll out, no lockdown and large gatherings are concerning doctors in Pakistan.

item.title: Israel crush: Witnesses tell of people 'thrown up in the air'
item.description: Those at the Lag B'Omer festival, where dozens died, say they were "swept along" by the crowd.

item.title: Xueli Abbing: The abandoned baby who became a Vogue model
item.description: The 16-year-old's albinism led to her being abandoned as a baby but she is now a successful model.

item.title: Man City beat Palace to close in on title
item.description: Manchester City could clinch the Premier League title on Sunday after two goals in the space of 83 seconds see off Crystal Palace.

item.title: 'Abuse needs to stop' - Ashley Williams & Alex Scott on social media boycott
item.description: Football Focus guests Alex Scott and Ashley Williams discuss a four-day boycott of social media by football clubs, players, athletes and a number of sporting bodies in an attempt to tackle abuse and discrimination on their platforms.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday in England and Northern Ireland end?
item.description: What is the stamp duty holiday and when will it finish?

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs are reopening, but what are the rules?
item.description: Northern Ireland follows England, Scotland and Wales in allowing venues to reopen outdoors.

item.title: Youngest Mastermind winner: 'It feels like a dream'
item.description: Jonathan Gibson won the competition by four points and got a perfect score in his specialist subject.

item.title: Empty gallery gives space to restore monumental painting
item.description: A painting by Edinburgh-born artist Robert Scott Lauder is the focus of a major conservation project.

item.title: Afghan interpreters rejected for resettlement fear death after UK exit
item.description: Campaigners say many interpreters fired for trivial reasons are being unfairly barred from the UK.

item.title: Oscars 2021: George Floyd's death prompted actor's movie role
item.description: Andrew Howard's movie won the best live action short film at the Oscars on a bumper night for Welsh stars.

item.title: Mourne Mountain fires: A community's devastation
item.description: The heartbreak as a community watches a huge fire destroy its mountains and local wildlife.
